Chakko, Sarah was an ecumenical leader who served as an elected president of the World Council of Churches (1951). She spoke at the World Council of Churches "First Assembly" held in Amsterdam in 1948. She was appointed to serve as an official delegate of the Syrian Orthodox Church to the World Council of Churches' "Second Assembly" in Evanston, Illinois (U.S.A.) but died in a sporting accident a few months before the meeting occured. As an educator from Trichur, Kerala in India, she was active in youth organizations sponsored by the Methodist church. She studied at the graduate level at several universities including taking an M.A. in Education at the University of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois (U.S.A.). She served for nearly a decade as the principle of Isabella Thoburn College in Lucknow, India. In 1952, she hosted the first World Council of Churches Central Committee meeting in Asia at the college.

note.quote: Bp. and scholar.

abstract.note: Child Emperor who ruled for a short time in AD 474
Rhetor of Alexandria denounced by Severus of Antioch
In hagiography: Munyatos was a saint in the Maronite calendar.

The wonder-working monk Daniel the Doctor, a disciple of Mar Awgin, also healed Miles, the son of the governor of Tel Ḥesh. Miles was consecrated Bishop of Tel Ḥesh and was stoned to death under Shapur.
In hagiography: Saba Gushnazdad was a monk from Beth Lashpar. He was a Zoroastrian convert who became a monk and converted many Kurds.
In hagiography: Mamelhta was a virgin and martyr from Beth Garmai. She was known in the Greek martyr Acts as Mamlaha, Mamlahtina, Mazahia or Malpetha.
Thyrsus and Lucian were martyrs in the time of Decius. Callinicus was a pagan priest who was converted to Christianity after witnessing their death.
In hagiography: Qashish of Ḥaḥ was a monk mentioned in John of Ephesus'Lives of the Eastern Saints. He went on pilgrimages and helped the Empress Theodora to build a hostel for the Miaphysites.
Simeon the Elder is commemorated in Simeon the Elder (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 17134, f. 74r and add. 18816, f. 102r.
Catholicos of the Church of the East (731–740 or 741) and the subject of hagiographical texts.
Theodute the courtesan was a courtesan who became a saint.

Cyriacus and his mother Juliette were martyrs. They were martyred under Diocletian in either Iconium, Tarsus, or Antioch, together with many others. Juliette was martyred with her son of three years of age, Cyriacus.
Joseph was the adopted father of Jesus.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a bishop of Edessa who transferred the relics of St. Thomas to Edessa in 394.
According to tradition, Babai was a sister of Sharbel and a convert from paganism. She was martyred in Edessa in the reign of Trajan.
Sosiana is commemorated in John and Sosiana (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 125v-127.
Candida was the daughter of the soldier Trajan, who came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
ʿAbdishoʿ was the teacher of Mar Qardagh.

In hagiography: Briḥisho was the brother of Yawnan. They were two brothers from Beth Asa who travelled to a neighboring village to encourage more martyrs. According to tradition, they died during the time of Sapor.
Hyperechius is commemorated in Hyperechius, Philotheus, Jacob, Paragros, Ḥabib, Romanus, and Lollian (The Seven Martyrs of Samosata) (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts.

Pamphilus is commemorated along with Vales, Seleucus, Paul, Porphyry, Theophilus, Julianus, and One Egyptian in Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paulus, Porphyrius, Theophilus, Julianus, and an Egyptian (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 247-250.

title.title: Ishoʿ bar Nun — ܝܫܘܥ ܒܪ ܢܘܢ

abstract.note: Ishoʿ bar Nun is a monk who is commemorated with Youssef Bousnaya. They were linked to the monastery of Rabban Hormizd.
Pāpīyōs is a martyr commemorated with Vīqṭōrīnōs, Vīqṭōr, Nīqāpōrōs, Dīyādōrōs, and Papias.
Sergius is commemorated in Simeon and Sergius (text) which features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Anonymi 1743 is commemorated in Brothers of Oxyrhynchus (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.

Gorgonia is sister of Gregory of Nazianzus. She was a pious wife and mother. She is commemorated in Gorgonia (text), a work surviving in at least 9 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Or. 8731, f. 38-42.
Theodore is commemorated in Elijah and Theodore (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 83-86.
Ananias is commemorated in Ananias and Shmouni (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Cambridge (Mass.), Harvard University Library, Syr. 59, f. 14 ff..

Anthony the General is commemorated in George the Martyr, Antony the Soldier, and Alexandra the Queen (text), a work surviving in at least 14 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 75 (Sachau 222), f. 226-234v.
Abel of Adiabene is commemorated in Abel of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).
Sabas is commemorated in Sabas (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .

In hagiography: Sleepers of Ephesus were the protagonists of a legend set in the time of the emperor Decius. Seven or eight children of Ephesus were entombed in a cave with their dog Qitmir until they awoke 190 years later. The legend dates to the middle of the fifth century.
Eupraxia (Ewpraksiyā) and Olympias were martyrs.
Abraham the Recluse is a saint who features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.

Shahdost is commemorated in Shahdoust and his Companions (text), a work surviving in at least 7 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, or. oct. 1256 (Assfalg 26, olim Abbeloos, dein Bedjan, copié sur ms Diyarbakir, Archevêché chaldéen, cod. 96 [nunc Mardin, Évêché chaldéen, y vu en 1969]), p. 412-419 and du ms Berlin,Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 75 (Sachau 222), f. 326-328.
Aha of Adiabene was the son of a priest from Arbela.
Salomon is commemorated in Salomon (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 34v.
Sampson is commemorated in Sampson (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts.
Shahloupa of Adiabene is commemorated in Shahloupa of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).
Eulogius was an ascetic who was a disciple of Mar Awgin. He was either a servant of a lion or of a leper.
Abraham the Priest features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Sabinius is commemorated in Sabinius (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14651, f. 113-126.

Abel is a biblical figure commemorated in Cain and Abel (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 57 (Sachau 174-176), f. 148a-150a. He is the son of Adam and Eve, killed by his brother Cain.

Apalin was a desert ascetic known for his intense fasting. He crossed rivers on the back of crocodiles which he later slew. He was commemorated in the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Isaiah is commemorated in Paesius and Isaiah (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Gordios is commemorated in Gordios (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Syr. 161, f. 149-155v.
Tribunus was a devout layman and ascetic disciple whose life was recorded in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints .

Pappas is commemorated in Pappos and 24000 Martyrs in Magdala near Antioch (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Damas, Patriarcat syrien orthodoxe, cod. 12/18 (olim ms Dayr az-Za‘faran, cod. 19), f. 119-121v.
Ishoʿ of Kumateh is a monk who is commemorated with Youssef Bousnaya. They were linked to the monastery of Rabban Hormizd.
Panbo is commemorated in Panbo (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Phocas is commemorated in Procopius and Phocas (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 12159, f. 148-150v and ms Vatican, Syr. 141, f. 114v-118.
Brīkhīshōʿ and his ten companions were martyred in the time of Shapur; they emerged in the context of a battle.
In hagiography: Awdisho was a bishop and martyr of Kashkar.
ʿAzāzāʾēl was an illustrious youth from the Orient who travelled to Rome and was martyred under Maximinus.
Thyrsus and Lucian were martyrs in the time of Decius. Callinicus was a pagan priest who was converted to Christianity after witnessing their death.

Mary is commemorated in Theophilus and Mary (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 7190, f. 333v-336v and Add. 14730, f. 112-121 (mutilé du début).
John is commemorated in John, Arcadius, Xenophon, and Mary (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 236, f. 145-157.
John of Adiabene of Adiabene was bishop of Arbela during the reign of Shapur II.

title.title: Constantine, bishop of Edessa — ܩܘܣܛܢܛܝܢ ܕܐܘܪܗܝ

abstract.note: In hagiography: Constantine was a seventh-century bishop of Edessa who may be the Constantine commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
Quriyos was a martyr of Ḥarran under Caliph Al Mansur.
In hagiography: Mar Dodo (Dada) was a saint from Ṭur ʿAbdin and a companion of Mar Awgin. There is a church in Beth Sbirino dedicated to him.
Theodule is commemorated in Alexander and Theodule (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14654, f. 27v-31v (mutilé).
In hagiography: Peroz of Beth Lapat was a high born Zoroastrian who became a Christian and was martyred before Bahram V.
Simeon Salos was a holy fool of the city of Emesa.
Macarius of Alexandria came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Qardag was a military saint and a martyr. He was a convert from a high-born Zoroastrian family. His cult was localized north of Arbela. His teacher was Mar Abdisho.
Timothy is commemorated in Timothy (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, 238r-v.
In hagiography: Saʿad (or Saʿdu) was bishop of Edessa and finished the cathederal begun by Quna.
Mama was a martyr of Beth Sloth.

title.title: Moses of Beth Sayyare — ܡܘܫܐ ܕܥܘܡܪܐ ܕܒܝܬ ܨܝܪܐ.

abstract.note: Moses of Beth Sayyare helped to restore the monastery of Beth Sayyare which was founded by Mar Abraham, a disciple of Mar Awgin.
In hagiography: The martyrs of Nagran, led by Arethas, died in Ḥimyar, condemned by Joseph, a Jewish governor.

title.title: Narsai, son of the covenant — ܢܪܣܝ

abstract.note: Narsai was a monk and martyr. He was decapitated. He was a of Beth Garmai with his disciple Joseph.
In hagiography: Qawma was a monk and dendrite saint from Beth Garmai. His body did not decay.
In hagiography: Macarius and Eugenius were priests and martyrs who were decapitated.

Mar Malke was a monk whose story overlaps with Mar Awgin. He was the son of Awgin's sister, Rebecca. He was from Clysma. He gave to the poor and joined his uncle on Mt Izla. He built a monastery near Ankah near Midyat. He performed miracles and journeyed to Jerusalem.
Sābā Pirgushnasp was a child martyr. He was the child of the governor of Beth ʿArabaye. He was martyred under Shapur II at the age of 12.
Theon is commemorated in Theon (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
In hagiography: Michael and his sister (Shiris?) were martyred outside the gate of Mardin in a place called the Monastery of the Fish or the Monastery of the Column.
Timirion is commemorated in Tamiroun (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
In hagiography: Cyprian and Justina were martyrs from Antioch who died under the emperor Diocletian.

Cyriacus was a martyr under the Emperor Julian. He was also known as Judas Cyriacus, and he was a convert from Judaism through his mother, Anne. They were martyred together. He was thrown into a pit of snakes.
John of Hephaestopolis features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints. He was a leader in the resistance of eastern bishops against the council of Chalcedon.

In hagiography: Awida was a Persian confessor whose ears and nose were cut off; he had wanted to follow Yazidpanah to martyrdom. Yazdapnah was a magian from a village near Karka de Ledan in Beth Huzaye(Huzistan). He stayed five years in prison before the martyrdom of Gregory Pirangusnasp.

Azad is commemorated in Jacob and Azad (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, or. oct. 1256 (Assfalg 26, olim Abbeloos, dein Bedjan, copié sur ms Diyarbakir, Archevêché chaldéen, cod. 96 [nunc Mardin, Évêché chaldéen, y vu en 1969]), p. 531-537.
Metrodore is commemorated in Faustinus and Metrodore (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Oxford, Bodleian Library, Syr. 138 (Bodl. Or. 19), f. 171-186v.
Bessarion is commemorated in Bessarion (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Bābūlā (Babylas) was a Bishop of Antioch who died from poor treatment in prison; he demanded that Emperor Philip the Arab make public penance.
Jacob was a martyr of Samosata.
Patricius is commemorated in Patricius and his Eleven Companions (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Rich. 7192, f. 66r-v (mutilé du début).
Germanus is commemorated with Antoninus, Mannathus, and Zbīnā in the History of Martyrs of Palestine by Eusebius of Caesarea

Paul, Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah are commemorated in Paul, Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 250r-v.
The biblical apostle Philip.
Hadrian and Eubulus are commemorated in Hadrian and Eubulus (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 250.
Antoninus is commemorated with Zbīnā, Mannathus, and Germanus in the History of Martyrs of Palestine by Eusebius of Caesarea
Anonymous 2088 is commemorated in Solitary (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 47v.
Ananias is commemorated in Ananias (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Mardin.
Acacius was a martyr during the reign of Maximinus II.
In hagiography: Stephen was a superior of a covenant. He was commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Elisha of Tanhir was commemorated by Rabban Saliba. Little is known about him nor about the location of Tanhir.

Behnām and his sister Sara were high-born Christian martyrs who were the children of Sennacherib. They converted to Christianity through a monk, Mattai, and were killed by their father. Their father later repented and became a Christian and with his wife. Sennacherib and the queen built monasteries for Mar Mattai and Abraham near Mosul.
In hagiography: Elijah was an ascetic commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Elijah was the bishop of ʿAyn Ward and the first bishop from the monastery of Simeon of Qartmin. He knew Theodute.
Shahpur is a Persian martyr from the time of Shah Yazdgird.
Sampson of Adiabene is commemorated in Sampson of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus, Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
Abn is an ascetic who came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius. He calmed a violent hippopotamus.
Acacius of Aleppo was a bishop of Aleppo veneratd by Balai.
In hagiography: Eugenius and Macarius were priests and martyrs who were decapitated.
Amoun knew the priest Apollo.

The widow Sophia and her daughter Euphemia quarter a Goth in the Roman army in Edessa. The Goth forces Sophia to give Euphemia to him in marriage, but he then enslaves her. The intercession of Sts. Shmona, Guria, and Habib saves Euphemia and returns her to Edessa.
Antony the Great of Egypt, father of monasticism. Also venerated in Syriac tradition.
Hala is commemorated in Hala (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 88-90 and Add. 14735, f. 157v-159v.
Anonymous 1741 is commemorated in Brotherly Neighbor of Poimen (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 55v.
Heronios and his wife are commemorated in Heronios and His Wife (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.

title.title: Gordian, father of Saint George — ܓܘܪܕܝܢܘܣ

abstract.note: Gordian was the father of the martyr St. George.
Paragros is commemorated in Hyperechius, Philotheus, Jacob, Paragros, Ḥabib, Romanus, and Lollian (The Seven Martyrs of Samosata) (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts.
Ignatius was a patriarch and maphrian.
Isidore is commemorated in Isidore (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Apphianus is commemorated in Apphian (text)

Cain is a biblical figure, the brother of Abel whose history is the subject of Cain and Abel (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 57 (Sachau 174-176), f. 148a-150a.
Noah is commemorated in Theodore and Noah (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Oxford, Bodleian Library, Syr. 163 (Marsh. 13), f. 97-113v.
Bākōs (Bacchus) was one of the most popular saints of the Orient. He was a Roman soldier who was martyred shortly before his friend Bacchus since he refused to sacrifice to the Roman gods.

In hagiography: Azad was a deacon of Beth Naggare in Adiabene who was martyred with the priest Jacob during the persecution of Shapur II. The executioner washed his bloody sword in a pool, and the blood desiccated the pool.
Baboi was Patriarch of the Church of the East during the Reign of the Sasanian shah Peroz.
John is one of the fathers of Egypt, commemorated with other Egyptian fathers in a poem by Timotheos of Gargar.
Tahsia is a penitent harlot commemorated in Tahsia (text). She came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.with Palladius.
Theodulos is commemorated in Theodule and Agathopous (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr.160, f. 126-135.
Mikhā of Nuhadra was the founder of a monastery or a church in the village of Alqosh, north of Mosul.
In hagiography: Sabbatius was a solitary monk who lived near the banks of the Euphrates.
In hagiography: Narsai, bishop of Sharqart, and Joseph his disciple, were martyrs of Beth Garmai.

In hagiography: Moses the Black (or Moses the Thief) was instructed and baptized by Macarius. He was a man of great physical and spiritual strength who performed many miracles and overcame adversity. He was killed by Bedouins who attacked his monastery.
Mihrsapor was a convert from Zoroastrianism who was imprisoned and died of hunger and thirst.
In Syriac hagiography, there is an attested saint named Nuhra. It may be that this name, Syriac for "light," is a translation of the Greek "Phocas" or the Latin "Lumen."
Theodosia is a martyr commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea his History of the Martyrs of Palestine. She was a virgin from Tyre.

In hagiography: Martha was commorated for being martyred in Rome with her husband, Mari, and children, Audifax and Abaq, while they were on a pilgrimage. They were taken in the persecution of Cladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.
Leontius of Tripoli was a martyr. He had been a Roman solider. There was a monastery named after him in which Severus of Antioch was baptized.

In hagiography: Diocletian fell in love with a young woman, Rhipsime, when he saw her picture. She lived a convent with 17 others, and they fled to Armenia. They were captured by the king Tiridates, who tortured and killed Rhipsime, her teacher Gayana, and the other virgins. Tiridates was turned into a boar. Gregory cured the king, and Armenia converted to Christianity.
In hagiography: Ruhana the Melodist was identified with Cyriacus, disciple of Euthymia in Palestine.
In hagiography: Mark was a solitary ascetic known from the life of Macarius in the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius. He was distinguished by his wrestling with the temptations of the flesh.

John is a desert father commemorated with Apollo, and he came into the Syriac tradition via the Syriac translation of Palladius. He wandered in the desert and was known for his ability to survive on little sleep, fast, and stand for long periods of time.

John of Lycopolis is an Egyptian father commemorated in John of Lycopolis (text). He had been a carpenter before he became an ascetic. He came into the Syriac tradition via the Syriac translation of Palladius.
In hagiography: Buṭlāna was a doctor and a martyr. His story was a Syriacized version of the life of Pantaleon.
Mar Dōdō was a convert from Zoroastrianism to Christianity. He was condemned to an ordeal of fire. He was martyred under Shapur II.
Aurelius is commemorated in Aurelius (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Barhadbeshabba is commemorated in Abraham, Cyriacus, Barhadbeshabba and Sergius in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.
In hagiography: Awdisho was an anchorite monk from the area near Arbela who converted the soldier-saint Qardag.
Barbaʿshmīn was a Bishop and martyr of Seleucia-Ctesiphon. He was arrested at Karka d-Ledan and martyred during the persecution of Shapur II.
Qazo and her brother Gourbarlaha were twins of Shapur II who were converted to Christianity through Dadu, a military officer from Medes. They were all put to death at Karka de Ledan.

Paul of Antioch is commemorated in Peter, John and Paul of Antioch (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Damas, Patriarcat syrien orthodoxe, cod. 12/16 (olim Jérusalem, Couvent syrien orthodoxe Saint-Marc, cod. 156 (Baumstark Litur. 43)), f. 36v-37v.
Paphnutius is commemorated in Paphnutius (text), a work surviving in at least 7 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Isaac of Adiabene is commemorated in Isaac of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).

abstract.note: In hagiography: Holy Innocents is the name given to the biblical children who were killed in the New Testament account of the massacre of the Innocents in Bethlehem under Herod the Great as related in the Gospel of Matthew.
Pelagia was a circus dancer and prostitute in Antioch, but she converted to Christianity and became a transvestite monk, "Pelagion," living in Jerusalem.

Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paul, Porphyry, Theophilus, Julianus, and One Egyptian are commemorated in Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paulus, Porphyrius, Theophilus, Julianus, and an Egyptian (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 247-250.

abstract.note: Anonymi 1745 are anonymous saints commemorated in Two Persian Brothers (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 51v-52.
Anna is commemorated in Mary, Mother of God, Simeon, and Anna (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 368, f. 28v-33v (lacune centrale).
Simeon the Solitaire is monk from Amida and features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Srāpīyōn is a martyr commemorated with Vīqṭōrīnōs, Vīqṭōr, Nīqāpōrōs, Dīyādōrōs, and Papias.
Sergius is commemorated in Severus, Theodosius, Anthimus, Sergius and Paul, Patriarchs (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 114-116.
In hagiography: Eusebonia was a martyr with Apollonius mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
Abraham the Egyptian is a monk from Egypt who came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Abraham is commemorated in Abraham, Cyriacus, Barhadbeshabba and Sergius (text) in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus. from John of Ephesus Lives of the Eastern Saints

In hagiography: Elijah of Ḥirta(al-Hira) was a monastic founder from the sixth century. He was an Arab, a Lakhmid, who joined the monastery at Mount Izla and became a disciple of its founder, Abraham. He drove away corrupt monks. He left Mount Izla and established a monastery near Mosul. He was widely venerated by the Arab Christians.
Abraham is commemorated in Abraham and Maron (text) in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.

In hagiography: Elijah was the Syrian Orthodox bishop of Antioch and a convert from the Melkite community. He was a monk from the monastery of Gubba Barraya. He was bishop of Apamea and later Patriarch of Antioch. He was esteemed by Caliph Al-Walid I who allowed him to build a church.
Abraham II of Adiabene II was a bishop of Adiabene
Shabbai was the first bishop of Merv.
In hagiography: Denha was a monk of the convent of Qabratha.
Serapion Sidonius was an ascetic who came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Simeon the Scribe features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Anthia is commemorated in Eleutheria, Anthia, and Qorabor (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 160, f. 211-215v and ms London, British Library, Add. 14654, f. 17v-22.
In hagiography: Shiris (?) and her brother Michael were martyred outside the gate of Mardin in a place called the Monastery of the Fish or the Monastery of the Column.

Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paul, Porphyry, Theophilus, Julianus, and One Egyptian are commemorated in Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paulus, Porphyrius, Theophilus, Julianus, and an Egyptian (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 247-250.
Anonymous 1988 is a saint commemorated in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.

title.title: Anonymous 1778 — A Rich Man and A Poor Neighbor

abstract.note: Irene was a high born girl born to pagans who converted to Christianity, refused to marry, and worked as a miracle-worker in the cities of Megedo, Kallinikos, Tella, and Nisibis. She was martyred.
Isaiah of Palestine was a monk of Scetis from Egypt whose writings on asceticism and the mystical life were formative for the Syriac monastic tradition.
Paul, patriarch of Antioch of Antioch was a Miaphysite patriarch of the sixth century whom John of Ephesus commemorates.
In hagiography: Barbara was a pagan girl converted to Christianity and killed by her father after tortures, perhaps during the Diocletian persecution.
Bassius is commemorated in Bassianus, Romanus, and Simeon (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 104v-105v.
Dadu, a military officer from Medes, converted Gourbarlaha and his sister Qazo to Christianity during the reign of Shapur II. They were all put to death at Karka de Ledan.

Barbara was the beautiful daughter of the pagan Dioscorus. He locked his daughter up in a tower. She converted to Christianity, and her father beat her and handed her over to be martyred. Her example inspired another Christian woman, Juliana, to come to her aid. Both women were martyred.
Athqen of Sis came northwards from Iraq to the area of Mount Izla and became the third superior of the monastery of Rabban Saliba.

Athanasia is commemorated in Andronicus and Athanasia (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ed(1): ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 235, f. 204v-209v and ms London, British Library, Add. 14649, f. 96-99v.
In hagiography: Rabban Buya was a monk who was from ʿAqra; he had many companions and an anonymous sister who was also venerated as a saint. Her tomb was in Shaqlawa.
John of Nhel is a seventh-century monk linked to the monasteries of Mar Aḥa and Mar Yoḥannan of Kamul.
In hagiography: John was a contemporary of Awgin and Aha.
Rūbēl was an ascetic warrior from Thrace who became a leader of a monastery of 35 monks. He lived near Nisibis and his life was dated to the time of Trajan.

In hagiography: Maʿna was part of a group of martyrs killed under Yazdgerd II and connected anachronistically to Shapor, bishop of Niqator and Isaac, bishop of Karka d-Beth Slokh. This group also included Abraham and Simeon.

In hagiography: Lazarus the Confessor was possibly a monk of Qartmin commemorated for martyrdom under a Persian general. His precise identity is contested. He may be the same as another Persian martyr of the same name, Lazarus.
In hagiography: Quna (or Conon or Yona) was the bishop of Edessa. He set the foundations for the new cathedral of Edessa which was finished by his succesor Saʿad.
Theodore was a military saint and martyr.
Theodute and his son is commemorated in Theodute and his Son (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 160, f. 173-175.
Alūmpiyā (Olympias) was a deaconess of Constantinople.
In hagiography: Nicholas figures in the Maronite calendar.
In hagiography: Mihrnarsai was a martyr of Tur Berʿain in Beth Garmai who was commemorated with his brother Adorparwa and sister Sultan Mahduk.
Thallelaios is commemorated in Thallelaios (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12159, f. 254v-255v.
Posi and his daughter Martha were Greeks deported to the Sasanian empire. They were martyred at Karka d-Ledan. Pōsi had been chief of the royal artisans.
Theodosius of Jerusalem was a fifth-century bishop of Jerusalem who opposed the council of Chalcedon.
Mark of Tarmuqa was a solitary Athenian in Ethiopia. Serapion visited him at the Mountain of Tarmuqa.
Rōmānōs was a deacon and a martyr from Caesarea Palestine. He died in the persecution of Diocletian.
Anonymous 2139 is commemorated in Naked Elder (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 46.
In hagiography: Qayyuma of Baz was a monk. He evangelized the region of Baz near Hakkari.
In hagiography: Longinus was an asecetic and a martyr with Bassus and Suzanna, converts from Zoroastrianism whom Longinus baptized. A martyr named Stephen is also commemorated with them.
John of Helephta was a Rabban from the area of Marga.
John lived in Decapolis and was a healer.
Job the Just is a biblical patriarch known for his patience in suffering.

title.title: Daniel of the Monastery of the Dung Beetles

abstract.note: In hagiography: Daniel of the Monastery of the Dung Beetles was a refugee from Amida and student of Mar Mattai (his story mirrors the one of Behnam). He established a monastery near that of his teacher, Mar Mattai, with whom he had fled from Amida. The monastery he established was called the monastery of the yellow source. There was a miracle of protective beetles connected to this monastery.
Kresṭīnā Yazdūy from Karka d-Beth Slokh was the daughter of a Zoroastrian governor who was martyred after her marriage.
In hagiography: Habib, with is father Gamaliel, was celebrated in the calendar of Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Bassus and his twin sister Suzanna were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. A martyr named Stephen is also commemorated with them.
Euphemia is commemorated along with Mary in Mary and Euphemia (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 40-45 and Add. 14651, f. 70v-81.

Benjamin, son of Jacob is the biblical patriarch from the book of Genesis in the Hebrew Bible. The favored youngest son of Jacob and Rachel, he was also the favorite of his older brother Joseph. The two were commemorated together in the Syriac hagiographic tradition.
Bāday was a priest and Persian Martyr who was flagellated in a garden with pomegranate branches at the command of Mihrnarsai.
In hagiography: Athanasius was a bishop from Qenneshrin.
Barlaha is a child martyr from among the martyrs of Palestine.

In hagiography: Miles was a Bishop of Susa. He was born near Tehran and converted from Zoroastrianism. He went on a long pilgrimage and opposed the manner of leadership of Catholicos Papa. He was imprisoned with his son Narsai and beaten by the governor Hormizd. The priest Aboursam and the deacon Sinai died with him.

Papa is commemorated in Abda, Hasho, Isaac, Ephrem, Papa, Dadouq, Dourtan and Papa (text). He was martyred under shah Yazdegerd with companions Afrem, 'Abda, Jacob, another Papa, Daduq, and Durtan the learned.
Innocent is commemorated in Innocent (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.

In hagiography: Isaac, bishop of Karka was a bishop of Karka d-Beth Slokh who was martyred under Shapor II along with Shapor, bishop of Niqator. Their names was later associated with a group of martyrs killed under Yazdgerd II including Maʿna, Abraham, and Simeon.
Noah of Adiabene is commemorated in Noah of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).

Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paul, Porphyry, Theophilus, Julianus, and One Egyptian are commemorated in Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paulus, Porphyrius, Theophilus, Julianus, and an Egyptian (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 247-250.

Antigone is commemorated in
Sergius is commemorated in Sergius and Abraham of Kashkar (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 175 (Sachau 329), f. 126v-131v.

Ammonios is a martyr commemorated with Doticos, Cyriacus, and Acmonicos in Ammonios, Doticos, Cyriacus, and Acmonicos (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 312v-314v.

Serapion is commemorated in Serapion (text), a work surviving in at least 11 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 236, f. 194v-236v and ms London, British Library, Add. 14732, f. 132v-154.
In hagiography: Elijah the Younger of Heliopolis was a martyr from Damascus.

In hagiography: Miles was a Bishop of Susa. He was born near Tehran and converted from Zoroastrianism. He went on a long pilgrimage and opposed the manner of leadership of Catholicos Papa. He was imprisoned with his son Narsai and beaten by the governor Hormizd. The priest Aboursam and the deacon Sinai died with him.
Abraham of Nisibis is commemorated in Abraham of Nisibis (text)

In hagiography: Eutal (Awtal) was a disciple of Malke, son of Job of Ator, near Mosul. He was also known as "the Arab." He came to Malke for healing, and his tomb was at the monastery of Mar Malke in Ṭur ʿAbdin.
Abraham of Adiabene was an early bishop of Adiabene who was originally from Herdā.

In hagiography: Eutal of Magdala was a pagan who became a Christian in his youth. He abandoned his fiancée and became a monk with Mar Aba in Mopsuestia. He was a miracle-worker who converted thousands of pagans.
In hagiography: Elisha of Garbiya was a monk of Garbiya near Midyat.
ʿAbousha of Adiabene was a spiritual father originally from a village in the mountains called Tallpnā
Heronios and his wife are commemorated in Heronios and His Wife (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Amoun is commemorated in Amoun (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Sergius features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Anthimus was a sixth-century Miaphysite Patriarch of Constantinople who is commemorated by John of Ephesus in the Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Andrew is commemorated in Matthew and Andrew (text), a work surviving in at least 17 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 49v-57.

Paul, Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah are commemorated in Paul, Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 250r-v.
Gerasimos is commemorated in Gerasimos (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12174, f. 244v-246v.
Gaddai is commemorated in Gaddai (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
