Sergius features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Adam is the first man, according to the Bible, and he is commemorated in the second and third chapter of Genesis.

In hagiography: David of Ḥarran was the bishop of Ḥarran. He was originally a monk from Qartmin and a relative of Simeon of the Olives. He left all of his precious objects to the monastery of Qartmin, including a manuscript containing a collection of canons.
Ephrem, Narsai, Abraham, Julian Saba, Jean, Michel, Job, Isaiah, and Bar Ṣauma of Nisibis were commemorated together in the calendar of the Church of the East.
Alexander is commemorated in Alexander and Theodule (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14654, f. 27v-31v (mutilé).
This is an anonymous saint who was commemorated by the poet Balai.
Romanus is commemorated in Hyperechius, Philotheus, Jacob, Paragros, Ḥabib, Romanus, and Lollian (The Seven Martyrs of Samosata) (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts.
Abraham is commemorated in Addai and Abraham (text) in the Lives of the Eastern Saints by John of Ephesus.
Abraham of Harran of Ḥarran.
Romanus is commemorated in Bassianus, Romanus, and Simeon (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 104v-105v.

title.title: Saint (one who spent 25 years in a cave)

abstract.note: Fiey is unsure if there are one or two saints with this name. We preserve that uncertainty. There was one Dometius was a martyr was in a hermit's cave, and the other was a doctor from Kurdistan who fave counsel to the emperor Valens. Both a martyr and a doctor by the name of Dometius are venerated in the area near Qilleth.
Sergius is commemorated in Sergius (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 17134, f. 40v-41 and add. 18816, f. 56r-v.

In hagiography: Demetrianus was commemorated as a bishop of Antioch. He was deported by the Persians after the conquest of the city in 256. The beginnings of the diocese of Gundishapur were attributed to him.
Shoubhalishoʿ is commemorated in Shoubhalishoʿ (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Syr. 467, f. 107-111.
Simeon the Mountaineer features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Paul is commemorated in Paul, Valentina, and Hatha (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 244-245v.

Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paul, Porphyry, Theophilus, Julianus, and One Egyptian are commemorated in Pamphilus, Vales, Seleucus, Paulus, Porphyrius, Theophilus, Julianus, and an Egyptian (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 247-250.
The biblical prophet Habakkuk.
Onesimus is commemorated in Onesimus (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 12174, f. 344v-347v.
Isaac is commemorated in Isaac (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 109v-110v.
Nicephorus is commemorated in Charisios, Nicephorus, and Papias (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 314v-316.
Paul is commemorated in Paul of Pherme (text)
Eubulus and Hadrian are commemorated in Hadrian and Eubulus (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 250.
Barḥaḏbshabā was a deacon of Arbela who was condemned to death during the persecution of Shapur II.
Apollonios was a deacon in Egypt who was martyred in the time of the emperor Diocletian. His example converted Philemon and the judge Arrian, who were subsequently martyred.
Photius is commemorated in Peter and Photius (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 127r-v.

In hagiography: Bar Ŝewya or Bar Shabba was a solitary and first bishop of Merv; he was deported from Byzantine territory to Ctesiphon. The sister or wife of Shapor, Shirawan, became Christian and built a church there which Bar Shabba consecrated.

Behnām and his sister Sara were high-born Christian martyrs who were the children of Sennacherib. They converted to Christianity through a monk, Mattai, and were killed by their father. Their father later repented and became a Christian and with his wife Queen Shirin. Sennacherib and Shirin built monasteries for Mar Mattai and Abraham near Mosul.

title.title: John the Silo-Dweller — ܝܘܚܢܢ ܕܥܡܪ ܒܒܐܪܐ

abstract.note: John the Silo-Dweller or "John who lived in a well" is commemorated in John the Siloitus (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms Oxford, Bodleian Library, Syr. 163 (Marsh. 13), f. 232-243.
This is Jonah of the Book of Jonah.
John of Rome was the son of Eutropius and Theodora, believing parents. His parents constructed a shrine for their son.
Anonymous 2134 is commemorated in Widow of Jerusalem (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 234, f. 291-293.
In hagiography: Maron of ʿAyn Ward was a superior of the monastery of Qartmin and was mentioned in the life of Samuel of Qartmin. He baptized 2000 people in Mesopotamia.
Theodore Castrensus is commemorated in Theodore Castrensis (text) in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Mar Pinḥas was a martyr from the fourth century. He was from Qardu, and he was a disciple of Mar Awgin.
In hagiography: Maura and her husband Timothy were Egyptian martyrs. They were killed for refusing to burn their copies of Christian scripture.

Onesima was the daughter of a king and hermit in Egypt. She was mentioned in the hymns on the holy women and many liturgical pieces. She fled her royal house to become a hermit with 40 other nuns, and she feigned madness.

After her mother died, Marina entered the monastery with her father. She disguised herself as a man, Marinos. A woman blamed her for her pregnancy, and she was expelled from the monastery. She miraculously nursed the baby. Her sex was discovered after her death. Among the Syrians, she was venerated by the Maronites.
In hagiography: Martha was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred with Thecla in Adiabene.
In hagiography: Polychronus was a bishop and a martyr. He was probably a deported Greek who became bishop of Babylonia.
Victorinus is a martyr commemorated with Victor, Nicephorus, Diodore, Serapion, and Papias.
In hagiography: Mari of Beth Sahde was mentioned two times by Rabban Saliba.
Theopompus is commemorated in Theopompus, Theonas, and Friends (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 270v-285v.

In hagiography: Daniel of Galash was a married man who left his wife to become a monk. He met many ascetics in his life, including Mari and Julien Saba. He visited the portrait of Christ in Edessa. He stayed in a cave with Mari, and then he established a monastery on Mount Aysum. His son Lazarus became his disciple. He built a small monastery in Rome for his father.
This John refers to John the apostle and John the evangelist, whom early Christians commemorated as the same person.

In hagiography: Bassus and his twin sister Suzanna were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. A martyr named Stephen is also commemorated with them. At least one monastery commemorating Mar Bassus was founded near Apamea.
Arethas was a leader of the martyrs of Najran, whose story was brought to the attention of the Roman Empire through Simeon of Beth Arsham.

Apollo the Younger was a deacon, monk and martyr. He converted the singer Philemon, who was also martyred with him. He was commemorated in the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.

Aseneth is a biblical figure mentioned in the Book of Genesis as the wife of Joseph and the daughter of Potiphar. She and Joseph were the subject of a an extra-biblical literary tradition in Christian hagiography.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a hermit and priest from Dara; he was ordained by Barsai of Edessa and travelled to Mount Sinjar. He converted Maʿin; both Benjamin and Maʿin were martyred.
Basil is commemorated in Ignatius, Patriarch and Basil, Maphrian (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 196 (Sachau 198), f. 38v-39.
Hosea is a prophet of the Hebrew Bible commemorated by Yaʿqub of Serugh.
Nicholas of Myra was a bishop of Myra and miracle-worker.

Gregory the Illuminator the illuminator is a saint to whom the conversion of Armenia is attributed. He is the patron of the Armenian church and is commemorated in Gregory the Illuminator (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Damas, Patriarcat syrien orthodoxe, cod. 12/18 (olim ms Dayr az-Za‘faran, cod. 19), f. 16-22v.
Peqida of Adiabene is commemorated in Peqida of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).

Gewargīs is commemorated in The Relics of George (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Aqra, Bibliothèque épiscopale chaldéenne, cod. 54 (Vosté), cah. 12, f. 5v-10v and cod. 55 (Vosté), cah. 7, f. 7v - cah. 8, f. 2v.
Paul the Priest is commemorated in Paul, the Priest (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 378, f. 21-22.
Andronicus was a married man from Alexandria. His wife was Athanasia, and when their children died, they lived apart as monastics.
Shmouni is commemorated in Ananias and Shmouni (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Cambridge (Mass.), Harvard University Library, Syr. 59, f. 14ff..
Simeon is commemorated in Simeon and Sergius (text) which features in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
A 4th century Egyptian monk who wrote about the martyrdom of the forty fathers of Sinai
These are three Greek theologians who are commemorated together in the Church of the East: Theodore of Mopsuestia, Diodore of Tarsus, and Nestorius of Constantinople.
In hagiography: David was a saint commemorated on the 25 of September by Rabban Saliba.
Agape was a virgin martyred with her mother Sophia and her sisters Pistis and Elpis.
Romulus is a martyr of Palestine commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea.

In hagiography: Ezekiel was a monk who was born on the same day as the Emperor Constantine the Great. He was a Jew from the tribe of Manasseh who went to Egypt and became a disciple of Mar Awgin. Mar Awgin and his disciples left for the region of Adiabene and Beth Garmai. They went to Maḥoze and baptized the entire city, after they healed the sick. Ezekiel went around the region converting the "Magians." He founded a monastery near Daduq. He ended his life in the region of Kirkuk.
In hagiography: Eutychios was a Mesopotamian martyr under Al-Walid. He was also known as “Eustathios,” and he died for refusing to convert to Islam.
Romulus is commemorated in Romulus, Eudoxius, and Friends (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 12174, f. 395-397v.
In hagiography: Daniel the Stylite was a monk and disciple of Samuel of Qartmin who walked along the Tigris while he went to the land of Qardu (Gazarta).

Amantalida was an eighty-year-old desert mother of the city of Antinoe in Egypt who lived in a community of virgins as their teacher. She came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
In hagiography: Ten brothers of Qartmin are remembered as a group of monks who took part in a fight with villagers from Qartmin over the body of Simeon of Qartmin.
Simeon is commemorated in the Forty Martyrs of Sebaste (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 368, f. 42-50 and Syr. 369, f. 85v-90v.

title.title: Shamuni, mother of the Seven Maccabean Martyrs — ܡܪܝܡ

abstract.note: In hagiography: Shamuni, mother of the Seven Maccabean Martyrs was the biblical mother of the seven sons whose death is told in the book of 2 Maccabees. Although although unnamed in the biblical account, she was commemorated as a martyr in the Syriac tradition under the name Shamuni or Mary. In the Syriac account, she and her sons were martyred in Antioch in Syria.
Andronicus is commemorated in Probus, Tarachos, and Andronicus (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 12174, f. 430-438.
Gelasia is commemorated in Gelasia (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.

Paul is commemorated with Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah in Paul, Nilus, Patrimytheas, and Elijah (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 250r-v.
Hiran of Adiabene is commemorated in Hiran of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).
Baruch is a biblical prophet and contemporary of the prophet Jeremiah. He was commemorated as a saint in several Christian traditions.

Candida was the Christian wife of the Persian emperor Vahran. She was a Roman prison of war whom the other wives of Vahran despised, since she was beautiful and beloved by Vahran. She refuses to recant her Christian identity and is martyred.
Arsenius, king of Egypt is commemorated in Arsenius, King of Egypt (text), a work surviving in at least 15 manuscripts.
Benyamēn was a deacon and martyr under Vahram V.
Barshebyā or Shabbia was a monk who was the superior of a small monastery at Ishtahar, near Persepolis. He was martyred with ten others. His name means "son of the deported."
Apollo was a desert father who had been a blacksmith. He was commemorated in the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Thecla is commemorated as a sister of Mar Mar Awgin and Stratonike.
In hagiography: Daniel was the bishop of Edessa. He obtained relics of Severus of Samosata in order to chase demons away from the monks of the monastery of Qenneshre. He wrote a demonology.
Thomas the apostle is commemorated as the missionary to India India, and Christians in India call themselves "Thomas Christians" after his memory. There was cult to Thomas in the city of Edessa.
Anonymous 2137 who sat in a cave and performed ascetic feats was commemorated in the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Mari was the apostle to Mesopotamia. He was ordained by Addai to establish Christian communities in the royal cities of the Parthians.

Martha was a Virgin Martyr and the daughter of Posi. They were Greeks deported to the Sasanian empire. They were martyred at Karka d-Ledan. Her throat was cut like a young lamb on the day of Easter, 340.
In hagiography: Plato (or Platon) is known through the Acts of Plato which exist in Greek, Latin and Armenian. He was a bishop of Ancyra and a martyr under Maximinus.
While some hagiographical sources place Mar Awgin in the company of his two sisters, Thecla and Stratonike, Rabban Saliba includes Mary of Scetis in the company of the father of the monks.
Thomas is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v.
In hagiography: Sultan Mahduk was a martyr of Tur Berʿain in Beth Garmai who was commemorated with her brothers Mirnarsai and Adorparwa.

In hagiography: Mari and his wife Martha were Roman martyrs. Husband and wife, they went to Rome on a pilgrimage with their children, Audifax and Abaq, and they were taken in the persecution of Cladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.
In hagiography: Paul the interpreter commented on the Psalms. He might be Paul of Nisibis or Paul of Tella.
In hagiography: Pharkia was a scribe mentioned by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography:Maximus and Dometius were brother martyrs. They were brothers, the sons of Valentinian, who fled their father's palace to become monks in Palestine. They went to Egypt and met Macarius.
John the Small was an Egyptian monk who was a leader of the community at Skete.
In hagiography: Cyriacus (Quryaqos) was a disciple of Mar Yareth.
Joseph is a martyr from Persia who was killed with Ithallaha and Acepsimas.
Capiton is commemorated in Capiton (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .
Maximus is commemorated in Juventus, Longinus, and Maximus (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 17134, f. 42v-43 and add. 18816, f. 58v-59.
According to tradition, Barsamyā was an early Bishop of Edessa during the reign of the emperor Trajan and a contemporary with the Edessan martyrs Sharbel and Babai.
In hagiography: Boḥtisho was a deacon and a martyr who assisted Tomarsha in rebuilding churches destroyed under Shapur II. He was martyred under Vahram.
Arcadius is commemorated in John, Arcadius, Xenophon, and Mary (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 236, f. 145-157.
Polutina is commemorated in Paloutianos (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Damas, Patriarcat syrien orthodoxe, cod. 12/18 (olim ms Dayr az-Za‘faran, cod. 19), f. 25-30v.
Paul the Mourner is commemorated in Paul the Mourner (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 26v-28v.
Hapsay was a Persian martyr from the region of Arbela who was decapitated with Aitalaha, a former pagan priest who converted to Christianity.
Habib was a martyr of Samosata.
Shriʿa of Adiabene is commemorated in Shriʿa of Adiabene (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Berlin, Westdeutsche Bibliothek, Or. fol. 3126 (Assfalg 24).
Priest, goes with Amoun
Saba the Martyr is commemorated in Saba, martyr (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Orient. 1017, f. 205v.

The legend of Romanus and Dometius was Coptic, but it exists in Syriac also. The author places the story in the time of Theodosius II. The two brothers were said to be sons of the Emperor Valentinian who go to Palestine to become monks.
Agathopous is commemorated in Theodule and Agathopous (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr.160, f. 126-135.
Dānīʾēl (Daniel), a priest, and his sister Warda were from Raziq, near Tehran. They were arrested two years after Bishop Miles of Tel Ḥesh. They were tortured and then decapitated.
Agnes was a virgin martyr from Rome.
Daniel the Doctor was a convert from paganism who travelled to the monastery of Pachomius, then to Mar Awgin and then Nuhadra. He healed Miles, the son of a Persian governor. He lived as a hermit.
Devotion to Saint Edna is widespread among Maronite Christians. Her name means "ear," and she is invoked for ear infections.

Alexandra was a virgin from Alexandria who fled the city and locked herself in a tomb. She never looked at the face of a man or woman before she died in her tomb. She came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
In hagiography: Stephen was a martyr who was commemorated with Bassus, Suzanna, and Longinus.

title.title: Saba of the Tour Mesatha — ܣܒܐ

abstract.note: Saba of the Tour Mesatha is commemorated in Saba of Tour Mesatha (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 164-178.
Abba Apollo of Scete
Silvanus are commemorated by Eusebius in his History of the Martyrs of Palestine. Silvanus had been a soldier from the region of Gaza.

Habib is commemorated in Zebinas, Lazarus, Maroutha, Narses, Elijah, Mahri, Habib, Saba, Berikhicho, Jonas et Chembaiteh (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, or. oct. 1256 (Assfalg 26, olim Abbeloos, dein Bedjan, copié sur ms Diyarbakir, Archevêché chaldéen, cod. 96 [nunc Mardin, Évêché chaldéen, y vu en 1969]), p. 646-664.

Harphat is commemorated in Ḥarphat (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 38v-40 and Add. 7190, f. 337v-338v and Add. 14730, f. 125-129v and Add. 14650, f. 186-188.

Gregory the Elder the elder is father of Gregory of Nazianzus who is a saint commemorated in Gregory (text), a work surviving in at least 9 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Or. 8731, f. 42-50v.

Paul the Hermit is commemorated in Paul the Hermit (text), a work surviving in at least 10 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 317 and ms London, British Library, Add. 12173, f. 55.
Anonymi 1995 is a saint commemorated in Two Naked Monks (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms Vatican, Syr. 126, f. 45v-46.
Nathaniel is commemorated in Nathaniel (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Paesius is commemorated in Paesius and Isaiah (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
In hagiography: Boḥtizad of Kurke was a saint mentioned in a single East Syriac calendar. There is a monastery named after him in the mountains of Northeastern Iraq.
Archelides the Roman
Longinus is commemorated in Juventus, Longinus, and Maximus (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 17134, f. 42v-43 and add. 18816, f. 58v-59.
Carnidos came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a superior of the monastery of Qartmin. He was a disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.
Joseph is a biblical patriarch who was sold into slavery by his brothers, the sons of Jacob. He became an advisor to the Pharaoh because of his ability to interpret dreams.
In hagiography: Peter of Alexandria was the seventeenth bishop of Antioch. He was martyred under the emperor Maximinus.
In hagiography: Metkarkana the Vagabond was commemorated in the Maronite calendar.
In hagiography: Mary was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred with Thecla in Adiabene.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus, Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
Thomas the Armenian is commemorated in Thomas the Armenian (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 69-73v.

Maʿin was a general of Shapur II. He became a Christian when he witnesses the martyrdom of Dōdō. He was baptized and arrested. He built 69 places of worship around Sinjar. He died at age 114 in a monastery that he built near Europos.
In hagiography: Mqadashta (or The Sanctified) was a sister of Tarbo and Catholicos Simeon bar Sabbaʿe.
Timothy is a martyr of Palestine commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea.
In hagiography: Shabra was a child saint commemorated near Midyat.
In hagiography: Michael of Tarʿil was commemorated as a disciple of Sabrishoʿ d-Beth Qoqa. He was commemorated at the eponymous monastery of Mar Mikhaʾil of Tarʿil in the region of Adiabene.
Theonas is commemorated in Theopompus, Theonas, and Friends (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 270v-285v.
In hagiography: Pethion was a monk and a founder of a convent north of the Greater Zab.

Paul of Edessa was a bishop from the Italian peninsula who left his see and travelled to Edessa where, in disguise, he was hired into service as a household servant by John of Edessa, a priest. The two lived a life of prayer and spiritual companionship. They travelled to Sinai. Back in Edessa, they interacted with Matthew the eunuch, a woman hiding in a monastery. They travelled to Jerusalem. Paul performed miracles and fled to Nisibis. John found him there, and Paul told him to return to Edessa. Paul died, and John died 8 months later. The story was set in the time of the Bishop Rabbula.
In hagiography: Mary was commorated as a martyr. She and her brother the priest Jacob were from the village of Tell Salila. She was martyred at Tel Dara under Shapur.
John is commemorated in John and Sosiana (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 125v-127.
John the Baptist is John the Baptist, son of Elizabeth and cousin of Jesus.
In hagiography: Aziza was a monk, born to Egyptian royal pagans, who became a companion of Mar Awgin and established a sanctuary in Zerāni, in the district of Gilu or Hakkari.
Arrian was a judge or governor in Egypt in the time of the emperor Diocletian. He was converted to Christianity on account of the examples of Apollonios and Philemon. Arrian was also martyred.
Dioscorus was a martyr in the time of Diocletian.
Bīshōy was monk and superior from the Nitrian Egyptian desert whose story was reproduced in Syriac recensions.
In hagiography: Barsai was a bishop of Ḥarran and then Edessa while Ephrem the Syrian lived in Edessa; he built the "Grand Baptistery" there.
Stephen is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v.
Jacob the Apostle the apostle, known as the brother of the Lord.

Narses is commemorated in Zebinas, Lazarus, Maroutha, Narses, Elijah, Mahri, Habib, Saba, Berikhicho, Jonas et Chembaiteh (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, or. oct. 1256 (Assfalg 26, olim Abbeloos, dein Bedjan, copié sur ms Diyarbakir, Archevêché chaldéen, cod. 96 [nunc Mardin, Évêché chaldéen, y vu en 1969]), p. 646-664.
Patrmoutis is commemorated in Copros and Patermoutis (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
The biblical apostle, Paul the Apostle, author of much of the New Testament. In hagiography, Paul is often commemorated with Thecla.
Philemon was converted to Christianity by the example of the martyrdom of Apollonios. This took place in Egypt in the time of the emperor Diocletian. Philemon was also martyred.
Aaron is an ascetic who came into the Syriac tradition via ʿEnanishoʿ's Syriac translation of the Paradise of the Fathers by Palladius.
Simeon is commemorated in Bassianus, Romanus, and Simeon (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 104v-105v.
Sisinnius is commemorated in Sisinnius (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6 .

Acmonicos is commemorated with Doticos and Cyriacus in Ammonios, Doticos, Cyriacus, and Acmonicos (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 14645, f. 312v-314v.
Sabrishoʿ of Beth Qoqa is commemorated as the founder of Beth Qoqa, southwest of Arbela. Among his disciples was Michael of Tarʿil.
Saba Gushnazdad is commemorated in Saba (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Borg. Syr. 91, f. 107v-121v.
Daniel of Scete was an Egyptian monk from the sixth century who was venerated in the Syriac tradition.
Agapios is a martyr of Palestine commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea.
Alosis is a Palestinian martyr commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea.

Shamona is commemorated in Euphemia and the Goth (text). Shmona and Guria were two martyrs who were killed in Edessa during the Diocletian persecution. There was great devotion to these saints in Edessa.
In hagiography: Elian was a third-century martyr from Emesa. He was a doctor and was executed by his own father. The bishop Paul built a church in his honor.
Shenoute is commemorated in Shenoute (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 236, f. 33-39.

In hagiography: the “Egyptians of Qartmin” were a group of 800 monks from Egypt who were buried at Qartmin. Their legend was connected to the crania in the monastery Qartmin. Eight hundred princes on pilgrimage from Egypt became monks of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Daniel of Qartmin was a monk of Qartmin who was elected bishop of Qartmin.
Agapios is a Palestinian martyr commemorated by Eusebius of Caesarea.

Saba is commemorated in Zebinas, Lazarus, Maroutha, Narses, Elijah, Mahri, Habib, Saba, Berikhicho, Jonas et Chembaiteh (text), a work surviving in at least 5 manuscripts including ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, or. oct. 1256 (Assfalg 26, olim Abbeloos, dein Bedjan, copié sur ms Diyarbakir, Archevêché chaldéen, cod. 96 [nunc Mardin, Évêché chaldéen, y vu en 1969]), p. 646-664.

Sahda is commemorated in Mar Beth-Sahda (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms Oxford, Bodleian Library, Syr. 163 (Marshall 13), f. 137-197v and ms Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, syr. 235, f. 73v-80.
Silvester was the bishop of Rome who, according to hagiographic traditions, baptized Constantine the Great.

Suzanna is commemorated in Susan (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14650, f. 178-182 and Rich. 7190, f. 336v-337v and Add. 14651, f. 94v-103v and Add. 14730, f. 121v-125.
Hermalaʾos is commemorated in Panteleon, Hermaloas, and Companions (text), a work surviving in at least 6 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12142, f. 87-104.

Hasho is commemorated in Abda, Hasho, Isaac, Ephrem, Papa, Dadouq, Dourtan and Papa (text). He was martyred under shah Yazdegerd with companions Afrem, 'Abda, Jacob, Papa, another Papa, Daduq, and Durtan the learned.
Philemon was humble priest commemorated by Palladius.
Paul the Simple is commemorated in Paul the Simple (text), a work surviving in at least 11 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Pachomius is commemorated in Pachomius - Ascetikon (text), a work surviving in at least 4 manuscripts including ms Lady Meux 6.
Narses was the bishop of Shaharqadt who was martyred with his disciple Joseph.
Jacob the Lame or "the Lame" was a wise man who came into the Syriac tradition via the Syriac translation of Palladius.
In hagiography: Barhadbeshabba of Qartmin was a monk and disciple of Samuel of Qartmin.
Apostles are saints commemorated in Apostles and Disciples (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Add. 18715, f. 246r (mutilé du début).
Zota is commemorated in Thomas, Stephen, and Zota (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including mss London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 45-51 and Add. 14650, f. 167v-172v.
Ares is commemorated in Ares, Primus, and Elijah (text), a work surviving in at least 2 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 12150, f. 246v.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a disciple of Mar Awgin. He travelled to Mount Izla and founded a monastery and school near Mardin. His vita may be a version of the life of Mar Miha.
Azād was a eunuch at the court of Shapur II who was martyred a week after Simeon Bar Sabbaʿe at the gate of the palace of Karka d-Ledan.
John son of Euphemianos is commemorated in John, Son of Euphemianos (text), a work surviving in at least 16 manuscripts including ms Vatican, Syr. 464, f. 52-61v.
In hagiography: Mary was the sister of Panteleon (Batala) and was commemorated with him.

In hagiography: Michael the Companion of Angels was a monk linked to Mar Awgin. In some traditions, he was the hagiographer of the Life of Awgin. He was commemorated with other monastic founders in Mesopotamia.
A Zoroastrian convert to Christianity martyred during the reign of Yazdegerd II.
Theonilla was a martyr in the time of Diocletian.
In hagiography: Sabellius and Shapira were the parents of the martyr, Talia. They conceived him when they were at the age of 52 years.
Trypho is commemorated in Trypho (text), a work surviving in at least 1 manuscript: ms London, British Library, Rich. 7200, f. 10v-14.
Thomas of Damascus is commemorated in Thomas of Damascus (text), a work surviving in at least 3 manuscripts including ms London, British Library, Add. 14647, f. 82v-83.
In hagiography: Muʿawiya was a martyr in Arabia who was thrown to the beasts.
